author: By Paula Span
title: Moving Is a Monumental Task for Many Older Americans. These Organizers Can Help.
description: Senior move managers may spend weeks or months helping seniors and their families sort through belongings, pack and move into a new home.
content: The four-bedroom house that Ray and Beth Nygren had lived in for 20 years in Auburn, Wash., measured about 2,400 square feet. The two-bedroom apartment that awaited them in a nearby independent- and assisted-living complex was less than half that size.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Fate Brought Them Together During a Blizzard in Buffalo. Then They Reunited in Seoul.
description: Months after a South Korean tour group landed at their upstate New York doorstep during a snowstorm, the couple who hosted them received a heroes’ welcome in Seoul.
content: About five months ago, in the middle of a deadly and ferocious blizzard, Alexander and Andrea Campagna answered a knock on the door of their home near Buffalo. Outside were 10 South Korean travelers whose van had become stuck in the snow on their street. The Campagnas welcomed the stranded travelers in, and, in doing so, provided a much-shared story of compassion and good will during a vicious storm just before Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Asmaa Elkeurti
title: 2 Bodies Found in Manhattan Rivers Are Identified as Missing Boys
description: Alfa Barrie, 11, and Garrett Warren, 13, had been missing for several days. The police said their investigation into the boys’ deaths was continuing.
content: The bodies of two boys, who family members said were together shortly before they disappeared over a week ago, have been recovered from separate locations in the waters off Manhattan, the police said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Tensions Flare Inside The Messenger, a Fledgling News Site
description: The company’s high-volume approach to digital publishing has led to duplicated stories and alienated some of its journalists. At least one editor has already resigned.
content: Executives at The Messenger, a news start-up, had big ambitions in the months leading up to its public debut. They said they would begin with 175 journalists covering entertainment and politics, change journalism for the better and even make its audience “fall in love” with media again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett and Hana Asano
title: There’s No Ocean in Sight. But Many Hawaiians Make Las Vegas Their Home.
description: The scenery can’t compare. So why are Hawaiians increasingly moving there?
content: When Pauline Kauinani Souza was a child in Hawaii, she spent early mornings watering her grandfather’s watermelons and papaya trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: How ‘Succession’ Busts One of America’s Most Cherished Myths
description: It’s fine to have money and power, as long as you don’t admit how much you want them.
content: My friends who have never seen “Succession,” the hit HBO show that will soon come to an end, say that they have no interest in watching rich people behaving badly. The darkly comic series certainly fits that bill: It follows the travails of the Roy family, the patriarch of which, Logan Roy, is an avatar of Rupert Murdoch, and whose children, Shiv, Kendall and Roman, jockey endlessly, and haplessly, to inherit his throne.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fleeing Envoys Trap Sudanese In a War Zone
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 20, 2023.
content: “The U.S. diplomats evacuated their own citizens but they didn’t think of the Sudanese. We are human, too.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisy Lafarge
title: A Closeted College Freshman Learns a Thing or Two About Adulthood
description: In Bronwyn Fischer’s debut novel, “The Adult,” an 18-year-old woman leaves her rural hometown for a big-city campus where she falls deep into a love affair — and poetry.
content: Bronwyn Fischer’s debut, “The Adult,” charts 18-year-old Natalie’s freshman year in college in Toronto. On arrival, Natalie’s first disappointment is the trees behind her dormitory. Thinking at first that they indicate a forest — like the trees of her remote, rural hometown, Temagami, Ontario — Natalie looks closer to find that “they had been planted narrowly together,” a uniformity lacking in depth and wildness. This introduces a string of more familiar undergraduate disappointments: the disquiet of a small-town introvert away from her parents for the first time; tenuous friendships forged through icebreakers and drinking games; wondering how she has ended up in classes with names like “Material Religion” and “Nature Poetry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: This Year’s G7 Summit Doubles as a Club for Unloved Leaders
description: The relatively weak approval ratings for President Biden and his Group of 7 partners highlight the fragility of free societies facing deep political divides.
content: They come from far corners of the globe, speak different languages, span the ideological spectrum and range in age from 43 to 80. But one thing President Biden and the other leaders of the Group of 7 meeting in Japan this weekend have in common? They’re not all that popular at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Gustavo Dudamel Leads His New York Philharmonic
description: Performing Mahler’s Ninth Symphony, the superstar maestro conducted the orchestra for the first time since being named its next music director.
content: Gustavo Dudamel began his reign at the New York Philharmonic on Friday with an ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
title: In Bakhmut, the Tides of Battle Are Ever Shifting
description: Ukraine, this month, pressed ahead with three days of maneuvers that gained ground on the flanks of Bakhmut. But Russian forces still appear to hold the center of the strategic city.
content: Ukrainian soldiers were waiting for just the right moment to attack. Then they received critical intelligence: Russian mercenaries on the other side of the front line outside Bakhmut were about to rotate out and be replaced by other soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: The key events in the battle for Bakhmut, the war’s longest-running sustained fight.
description: The city has for months been the center of the fighting in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine. Here’s a look at the critical moments.
content: The city of Bakhmut has for months been the center of the fighting in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, and the site of one of the longest and deadliest battles of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Hank Green, Novelist and YouTube Star, Announces He Has Cancer
description: In a video, Mr. Green said he was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma, a very “treatable cancer.”
content: Hank Green, a novelist and longtime host of quirky YouTube educational videos, announced on Friday that he was recently diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma, a form of cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Dana Rubinstein and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Democrats’ Phalanx Around Biden Has an Eric Adams-Size Hole
description: The New York mayor has loudly blamed President Biden for an influx of migrants, amplifying concerns many Democrats share but irritating Mr. Biden’s aides and weakening his political position.
content: The Democratic Party is following a standard strategy as President Biden seeks re-election: Do not criticize him publicly under any circumstances, lest it help Donald J. Trump or one of his acolytes take back the White House for Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: There Is a Reason Ron DeSantis Wants History Told a Certain Way
description: Certain anxieties over education have a familiar ring.
content: As you have probably seen by now, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has signed another bill that limits classroom instruction on racism and racial inequality. This one applies to colleges and universities, banning so-called divisive concepts from general education courses. I mentioned all this in my Friday column, tying it to the broader Republican effort to give public institutions the freedom to censor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Disney to Close ‘Star Wars’-Themed Hotel Less Than Two Years After It Opened
description: The planned closure of Galactic Starcruiser, an immersive role-playing attraction, comes as Disney seeks to cut overall costs by more than $5 billion.
content: After spending hundreds of millions of dollars to build an immersive “Star Wars”-themed hotel at Walt Disney World, Disney said on Thursday that, amid sweeping corporate cost-cutting, it would close the underperforming attraction in September, only about 18 months after it opened.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 20, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 20, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about Disney’s decision to cancel an office complex project in Orlando, Fla., misstated the name of a luxury hotel that Disney plans to shutter. It is the Galactic Starcruiser, not the Galactic Starship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: James de Jongh, Who Put Stories of Slavery Onstage, Dies at 80
description: His play “Do Lord Remember Me,” constructed from interviews with formerly enslaved people in the 1930s, was first staged in 1978 and has been revived multiple times since.
content: James de Jongh, a scholar and playwright best known for fashioning oral histories left by formerly enslaved people in the 1930s into “Do Lord Remember Me,” a 1978 stage work that painted an unflinching picture of the human cost of slavery, died on May 5 in the Bronx. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis and Ben Casselman
title: Even Flirting With U.S. Default Takes Economic Toll
description: Financial markets are still betting that Congress and the White House will strike a deal. But the uncertainty alone is having consequences.
content: As negotiations over the debt limit continue in Washington and the date on which the U.S. government could be forced to stop paying some bills draws closer, everyone involved has warned that such a default would have catastrophic consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: A Brief Guide to Martin Amis’s Books
description: The acclaimed British novelist was also an essayist, memoirist and critic of the first rank.
content: Martin Amis, a giant of British fiction in the late 20th century, died on Friday at 73. As the former New York Times book critic Michiko Kakutani wrote of Amis in her review of his 2000 memoir “Experience,” he was “a writer equipped with a daunting arsenal of literary gifts: a dazzling, chameleonesque command of language, a willingness to tackle large issues and larger social canvases and an unforgiving, heat-seeking eye for the unwholesome ferment of contemporary life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ Premieres at Cannes: First Reaction
description: Martin Scorsese directed this harrowing and deeply American true-crime drama set in the 1920s. Leonardo DiCaprio, Robert De Niro and Lily Gladstone star.
content: On Saturday, “Killers of the Flower Moon,” Martin Scorsese’s harrowing epic about one of America’s favorite pastimes — mass murder — had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, screening  out of competition. It’s Scorsese’s first movie at the event since his nightmarish screwball “After Hours” was presented in 1986, winning him best director. For this edition, he walked the red carpet with the two stars who have defined the contrasting halves of his career: Robert De Niro and Leonardo DiCaprio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Thanks to an app, 382 investors in Mage await another shot at the winner’s circle.
description: Think part fantasy football, part investing, part pure fun in horse racing.
content: They came from the owners’ suites, the second floor of the grandstand, the rail. From California and Michigan and beyond. They were not going to miss this moment. Their horse had just won the Kentucky Derby, and the winner’s circle beckoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
title: Behind the Scenes, G7 Nations Wrangle Over Ambitious Climate Commitments
description: The U.S. finds itself caught between defending President Biden’s climate change agenda and aiding allies intent on increasing their access to fossil fuels.
content: In theory, the world’s largest industrialized democracies have agreed to stop using fossil fuels within a little over a quarter-century and to switch to new sources of power such as solar and wind as fast as they can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Creature of the Internet
description: Erica Hsiung Wojcik offers solvers a challenging 66-word puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeking Cures for Loneliness
description: Readers, including Lady Gaga’s mother, discuss an essay by the surgeon general and offer suggestions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Markovits
title: For Javier Marías, Spy Fiction Was a Means to Study Humanity
description: “Tomás Nevinson,” the final novel by the late Spanish writer, sends a washed-up agent in search of a terrorist.
content: Early in “Tomás Nevinson,” Javier Marías’s final novel, the eponymous narrator quotes an unnamed “Spanish general” from an interview: “In the struggle against terrorism, there are some things that should not be done. If they are done, then they should not be spoken about. If they are spoken about, they must be denied.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At Manchester City, Clinical Success Leaves Outsiders Cold
description: City claimed its third straight Premier League title on Saturday. But admiring its excellence is not the same as accepting its methods.
content: As it turned out, Manchester City had already done all it needed to do. On Saturday night, Pep Guardiola’s team’s last remaining rival — a bone-tired, spirit-sapped Arsenal — finally stumbled and fell. For the third time in three seasons, Manchester City was untouchable at the summit of the Premier League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: How to Change a Life for 50 Cents
description: On my win-a-trip journey, a reminder that a fifth of the world’s people have worms.
content: MAKENI, Sierra Leone — Brace yourself for a gross fact: Some 1.5 billion of the world’s people have worms living in their bodies, weakening them and occasionally disfiguring them. Yet eliminating the worms is one of the most tantalizing and inexpensive of health fixes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: It’s Not That Simple
description: Robert Ryan’s Sunday puzzle pronounces itself a fun challenge.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: Inside the Life of Influencer Barbers
description: These self-proclaimed “architects of swag” work closely with celebrities, post regularly on Instagram and earn six figures, taking what can be a monotonous job to new levels.
content: I slide into a cushy leather chair in this bustling shop next to a small flooring business. The hum of clippers echoes throughout the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Wagner Chief Says Bakhmut Is Taken; Ukraine Rejects Claim
description: The head of the Russian paramilitary group said his forces had captured the eastern city, a claim Ukrainian officials were quick to deny even as they called the situation “critical.”
content: The head of Russia’s Wagner paramilitary group said his mercenaries had captured Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine on Saturday, a claim the Ukrainian military denied even as their soldiers have been forced into an ever shrinking patch of land inside the ruined city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Cannes: You’ve Never Seen a Holocaust Film Like ‘The Zone of Interest’
description: The disorienting drama from “Under the Skin” director Jonathan Glazer may be in the running for a major prize at the festival.
content: You might not know where you are when “The Zone of Interest” begins, and that’s by design. This new film from the director Jonathan Glazer, which has been hotly tipped for a major prize at the Cannes Film Festival since its premiere Friday night, opens on a bucolic picnic by the lake. Family members chat in German, wander off, attend to children and soak up the sun. And Glazer’s long, wide shots let us settle in, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Fesperman
title: John Banville Puts Two of His Detectives on a Murder Case
description: In a new novel, “The Lock-Up,” investigators from the novelist’s previous books join forces in 1950s Dublin.
content: Poor Quirke. He’s miserable again, and his greater misfortune may be that we, as readers, prefer him that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Duncan
title: Just Married. Now Pass the Scissors.
description: To celebrate the rite of passage, some women are opting for a mid-wedding haircut.
content: From breakup bangs to back-to-school trims, a change in hairstyle has long been a visual shorthand to recognize major milestones. The latest in a lifetime of momentous haircuts? The mid-wedding chop, a hair transformation that celebrates the start of a new chapter as a spouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Scheffler, Hovland and Conners Share the Lead at P.G.A. Championship
description: Jordan Spieth, who needs a victory at Oak Hill to complete the career Grand Slam, and Justin Thomas, who won last year’s tournament, just made the cut at five over.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Justin Rose, the golfer you remember but maybe have not thought all that much about lately in major tournaments, had hit two fairways all day. He had birdied as often as he had bogeyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Why It’s So Hard to Crack Down on Stoned Drivers in New York
description: Smoking marijuana while operating a vehicle appears to have become ubiquitous in New York City after the drug’s legalization. But it’s a trend, though illegal, that’s not easy to curb.
content: Since recreational marijuana was legalized statewide in March 2021, weed now seems ubiquitous on New York City roadways. At smoke shops, customers drive off after blazing up. In motion or at red lights, smoke wafts from car windows, the smell mingling with exhaust fumes in a pungent miasma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Ugly Tale of Migrants Displacing Veterans Makes Waves and Then Dissolves
description: The eviction in Newburgh, N.Y., became an instant talking point. The problem was that it apparently had not occurred.
content: The story seemed tailor-made for opponents of outsiders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
title: After a Show-Stopping Entrance at the G7, Zelensky Pleads for More Aid
description: He urged his supporters to stay the course and tried to convince fence sitters like India and Brazil that there is no middle ground.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine landed in Japan on Saturday determined to urge the wealthiest democracies in the world to stick with him as Moscow bets on the West growing fatigued by the cost and consequences of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Jim Brown Should Be Seen Fully, Flaws and All
description: Brown, who died on Thursday, demanded that people see more to him than strong athletic performances. In the 1960s, that was unusual for athletes.
content: For all his athletic prowess, all the heft he brought to his social activism, Jim Brown’s power sprang from his unyielding resistance to the narrow definitions imposed by American society on its Black citizens and, in his case, Black male athletes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, May 13-19
description: Readers struggled to identify a host for a machine.
content: This week, nacelle — which is a streamlined enclosure containing an engine or other machinery — was the word least found by players of Spelling Bee, while game was the word most found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: In ‘Platonic,’ the Sex Part Doesn’t Get in the Way. No, Really.
description: The new Apple TV+ comedy, starring Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne, proposes an atypical answer to the question of the “When Harry Met Sally” conundrum.
content: About 20 years ago, the husband-and-wife writing and directing team of Nicholas Stoller and Francesca Delbanco went to a joint bachelor-bachelorette party in Las Vegas. Delbanco knew the bride-to-be a little, but the bachelor had been a close friend since college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler and Ephrat Livni
title: The Optimist’s Guide to Artificial Intelligence and Work
description: The focus of much discussion is on how it will replace jobs, but nothing is inevitable.
content: It’s easy to fear that the machines are taking over: Companies like IBM and the British telecommunications company BT have cited artificial intelligence as a reason for reducing head count, and new tools like ChatGPT and DALL-E make it possible for anyone to understand the extraordinary abilities of artificial intelligence for themselves. One recent study from researchers at OpenAI (the start-up behind ChatGPT) and the University of Pennsylvania concluded that for about 80 percent of jobs, at least 10 percent of tasks could be automated using the technology behind such tools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: The E-Sports World Is Starting to Teeter
description: At least two organizations in America’s most prominent league for professional video game players are selling their teams, underscoring the industry’s uncertain future.
content: Six years ago, the Madison Square Garden Company, a group that includes James Dolan, the owner of the New York Knicks and the New York Rangers, announced a triumphant entrance into sports’ next frontier: a professional video game league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis and Jeanna Smialek
title: Why Is Inflation So Stubborn? Cars Are Part of the Answer.
description: Prices of new and used vehicles were supposed to recede quickly as supply chain problems dissipated. The market had other ideas.
content: ‌Car prices soared after the coronavirus lockdowns, and two years into the United States’ worst inflationary episode since the 1980s, the industry demonstrates that getting back to normal will be a long and lurching ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Bakhmut has exposed an ugly, personal feud between the Russian Defense Ministry and ‘Putin’s chef.’
description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, once a caterer for the Kremlin, has made capturing the city a personal obsession.
content: For nearly a year, Russia has waged a vicious battle to capture the Ukrainian city of Bakhmut, seeking a gain after months of embarrassing setbacks on the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: ‘Superpowers’
description: Plus, the best of the archive, found in New York Times Audio, a new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers and exclusive new shows which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Doug Mills
title: An Eye on the Sky Fine-Tunes the Golf Tournament Below
description: Few professional sports scrutinize weather forecasts like golf. The P.G.A. Championship, played in meteorologically challenging western New York, has been a test.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Well before daybreak on Thursday, Stewart Williams joined an urgent discussion in a small second-floor room at Oak Hill Country Club, near the nation’s northern border. The night had brought cool temperatures, clear skies and gentle winds — and that was a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis
title: Building Boom on Mykonos Reveals ‘Wretched’ Side of Greece’s Recovery
description: Investors are eager to cash in on soaring demand for luxury properties, but an attack on an archaeologist investigating building violations brought a darker underbelly to light.
content: Well-heeled vacationers descended from luxury hotels into the gleaming labyrinth of Mykonos’s historic old town on a recent evening, ogling gold jewelry and heading to bars offering pricey bottles of Veuve Clicquot. Tourists sailing the Aegean on 15-deck cruise ships ducked into designer boutiques on day trips of unbridled shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: National Treasure wins the 148th Preakness Stakes.
description: On a day marred by a death in Bob Baffert’s barn, his colt, National Treasure, edged out Blazing Sevens by a head to win the 148th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday and give his trainer a record eighth victory in the race.
content: On a day marred by a death in Bob Baffert’s barn, his colt, National Treasure, edged out Blazing Sevens by a head to win the 148th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday and give his trainer a record eighth victory in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Ben Kingsley Seeks Out the Performances That Transcend
description: The Oscar winner, now playing Salvador Dalí in “Dalíland,” talks about “Waiting for Godot,” D.H. Lawrence and the way Britten’s “War Requiem” helps him understand history.
content: Ben Kingsley takes his accolades seriously. Knighted in 2002 for service to the British film industry, he prefers to be addressed as Sir Ben.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Air DeSantis: The Private Jets and Secret Donors Flying Him Around
description: As the Florida governor hopscotched the country preparing to run for president, a Michigan nonprofit paid the bills. It won’t say where it got the money.
content: For Ron DeSantis, Sunday, Feb. 19, was the start of another busy week of not officially running for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: An Auction of Prosthetics, Mermaids and Creepy Dolls to Benefit Sea Turtles
description: Some of the more curious pieces of marine debris that wash ashore along the Texas coastline are being sold to support the rehabilitation of marine wildlife.
content: When Jace Tunnell spotted what appeared to be a leg on the Gulf of Mexico shoreline in Texas, he thought that his greatest fear — a body washing up on the beach — was coming true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nell Gallogly
title: Why Do Runners Still Race With Paper Pinned to Their Shirts?
description: Racing bibs have tags that help track and identify runners. But they are also a good place for sponsors’ names.
content: Trayvon Bromell had a problem. There was a stadium of fans awaiting him and he wasn’t ready to race. He needed a few safety pins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Former Trump Lawyer Describes Conflict Inside Legal Team
description: Timothy Parlatore, who withdrew this past week from representing the former president in the special counsel investigations, said he stepped aside over differences with a Trump adviser, Boris Epshteyn.
content: A conflict inside former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team erupted into public view on Saturday as one of his former lawyers went on television to attack one of his current lawyers, who has been the focus of ire from others on the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry and Todd Heisler
title: The Good (Even Saintly) Ship Dorothy Day
description: While the Vatican decides whether Dorothy Day is worthy of sainthood, New Yorkers can ride on a Staten Island ferry named in her honor.
content: As the newest Staten Island ferry grumbled across New York Harbor the other day, you could easily imagine the woman for whom it is named in contemplation by a window. Her dress plain, her white hair in a braided crown, her eyes seeking the divine in the green-gray waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paulette Perhach
title: Would You Take Financial Advice From A.I.?
description: The financial services industry is plotting how to incorporate tools like ChatGPT into its products. But humans will still be necessary to provide personal advice.
content: Paul Weiner, an artist, has been experimenting with artificial intelligence for the past year, generating A.I.-created visual disinformation and seeing whether he can get the images to spread. But recently, he turned to ChatGPT, a chatbot that has the ability to respond to complex questions, for a much different reason: With his 30th birthday looming, he decided to ask it for advice about retirement planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Alberta Is on Fire, but Climate Change Is an Election Taboo
description: For politicians, discussing climate change in a province enriched by oil money is fraught.
content: When I arrived in Alberta recently to report an upcoming political story, there was no shortage of people wanting to talk about politics and the provincial election on May 29. But, even as wildfires flared earlier than usual and raged across an unusually wide swath of forest, discussions about climate change were largely absent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Besonen
title: The ‘High-Handed Swindler,’ Walter Matthau and Me
description: Documenting the history of an East Village tenement whose original owner preyed on immigrants during New York’s Gilded Age.
content: The tenement on East Seventh Street where I live was built in 1893, when a financial crisis in the United States had started to corrode a fabled, materialistic and short-lived time known as the Gilded Age, chronicled most recently in the HBO series of the same name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: In Flood-Stricken Area of Italy, Residents Fear This Won’t Be the Last of It
description: Flooding upended tens of thousands of lives this week in Emilia-Romagna, a region that has also experienced drought in recent years.
content: When the floods hit in the northern Italian town of Lugo this past week, overflowing a local watercourse and sending water gushing into streets and the surrounding fields, Irinel Lungu, 45, retreated with his wife and toddler to the second floor of their home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Stulberg
title: For People to Really Know Us, We Need to Show Up
description: Community bonds grow when we live up to our obligations.
content: A few years ago, when I lived in Northern California, I often hiked under old-growth redwoods. The roots of these mammoth trees, stretching some 200 feet into the air above us, run only six to 12 feet deep. Instead of growing down, they grow out, extending dozens of feet to each side, enmeshing themselves with the roots of their neighbors. This is why we never see a lone redwood: They can survive only in a grove, bound together in obligation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Martin Amis, Acclaimed Author of Bleakly Comic Novels, Dies at 73
description: In books like “Money” and “The Information,” he created “a high style to describe low things,” as he put it. He found more renown as a critic, and a measure of unease as his famous father’s son.
content: Martin Amis, whose caustic, erudite and bleakly comic novels redefined British fiction in the 1980s and ’90s with their sharp appraisal of tabloid culture and consumer excess, and whose private life made him tabloid fodder himself, died on Friday at his home in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Cannes Film Festival
description: Among the films premiering are features from Martin Scorsese, Wes Anderson and Todd Haynes.
content: The Cannes Film Festival began this week with Maïwenn’s “Jeanne du Barry,” starring Johnny Depp as Louis XV, and ends on May 27 with a new Pixar film, “Elemental.” In between, there will be many screenings, many awkward standing ovations, many awards bestowed. This is the first year I (kind of) understand the difference between an “Official Selection” and “Un Certain Regard” and all the other golden palm-leaf designations I’ll see on marketing materials for Cannes-affiliated films in the coming months, so I’m paying close attention to the goings-on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack and Mike Osborne
title: If You’re Hearing About the Border, Someone Is Trying to Scare You
description: The Border Security Expo attendees didn’t know what was coming, but they hoped to turn a profit.
content: The U.S.-Mexico border was full of uncertainty in the days before May 11. Title 42, the Trump administration-crafted health ordinance that had been invoked millions of times to turn migrants back from the border, was about to expire, and nobody knew what to expect. Many predictions were lurid and sensationalistic: Masses of desperate people would pour into the country, flood the border towns first and then press northward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Classical Crescendo
description: For cool kids, symphony halls are getting hotter.
content: WASHINGTON — The orgasm heard around the world was reported by Magnus Fiennes, a composer and music producer who is the brother of Ralph Fiennes. After going to the Los Angeles Philharmonic in April, he tweeted about a woman sitting near him at Walt Disney Concert Hall who had a “loud and full body orgasm” during the second movement of Tchaikovsky’s Fifth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Negroni
title: Deadly Traffic in Suburbia Points to Deep-Seated Structural Problems
description: Cities are forced to confront century-old suburban sprawl that was first and foremost designed to keep cars moving rather than people safe.
content: New Yorkers have long asserted their rights over cars on the city’s streets, identifying with Dustin Hoffman in “Midnight Cowboy” who barks, “I’m walkin’ here!” at a cab that nearly hits him as he tries to cross the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What the Writers’ Strike Means for the Future of Hollywood
description: How will the conflict change the stories we tell onscreen?
content: Here’s my attempt to summarize the context of the Hollywood writers’ strike in three sentences. First, the entertainment business, floated on easy money and encouraged by the unusual conditions of the Covid era, committed itself to an unsustainable expansion — the great streaming experiment, in which every major brand would have a Netflix of its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can I Get Around a No-Pet Policy With an Emotional Support Animal?
description: If you need an emotional support animal to help treat the symptoms of a disability, your landlord must accommodate the request.
content: Q: I recently moved into a rental with a one-year lease. I chose this apartment in part because I thought I’d be able to get a dog. (The lease said “no pets without owner’s permission,” so I assumed a dog would at least be up for discussion.) However, the language in the welcome packet was stricter, saying, “no pets in the building, no exceptions.” One way around this would be to say that I need an emotional support animal. But my landlord might see this for what it is — a workaround — and not renew my lease when it expires. How would you handle this situation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Voices Optimism on Debt Talks Despite Sharp Statements by Both Sides
description: He said the recent harsh back-and-forth was posturing typical of any negotiation and predicted the two sides would still “get something decent done.”
content: President Biden on Saturday brushed off noisy statements issued by both sides in the debt and spending talks gripping Washington, dismissing them as little more than the posturing typical of any negotiation and expressing confidence that he will still be able to strike a deal with Republicans to raise the debt ceiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: The Island Destination Wedding a MetroCard Swipe Away
description: The Sanctuary, a new wedding venue on Roosevelt Island, has become a hot spot. But change doesn’t always sit well with the small waterfront community.
content: Last weekend at Paul Choi and Ashley Austin Morris’s wedding in a little stone church on Roosevelt Island, there was the sort of giddiness in the air that you might expect to find at an actual island destination wedding. That’s because most of their guests, despite years of living in New York City, had never stepped foot onto Roosevelt Island, the residential waterfront Manhattan community sitting in the East River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: Birds, Brooks and Beta Males
description: An editor recommends old and new books.
content: Hello Read Like the Winders,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Mayor Adams Improvises His Way Through an Impossible Crisis
description: The spontaneous governing style of the Adams administration struggles to adapt to the migrant housing crisis.
content: Last weekend, several Brooklyn principals were told that their schools would immediately be sheltering hundreds of asylum seekers, by way of mayoral fiat. The schools commandeered into service were chosen because they had stand-alone gyms, apart from the main buildings, which would separate children from the adults who would temporarily be staying there, side by side in tight rows of green cots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Rice. Half of Humanity Eats It. And Climate Change Is Wrecking It.
description: From the Mississippi to the Mekong, farmers and researchers are finding creative fixes for the dire threats of global warming, extreme rains and sea-level rise.
content: From the Mississippi to the Mekong, farmers and researchers are finding creative fixes for the dire threats of global warming, extreme rains and sea-level rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: More Than a Dozen People Killed in Northern Italy Flooding
description: At least 14 people died and thousands were left homeless after floods inundated the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy.
content: At least 14 people died and thousands were left homeless after floods inundated the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy.
source.name: The New York Times
